bibl.title: Memorandum of interview with William Crawford Gorgas, by Wickliffe Rose, July 14, 1914

div1.p: Rose and Gorgas discuss the relative severity of ankylostomiasis and malaria in Malaya, as well as plans to eradicate yellow fever worldwide.

div1.head: Memorandum of interview with William Crawford Gorgas, by Wickliffe Rose, July 14, 1914

p.hi: Memorandum of Interview with General Gorgas

div1.p:
Tuesday, July 14, 1914, General Gorgas called at my office by
appointment for conference on two matters which I wanted to talk over with
him. The following are the chief points covered in our discussion:

1. I outlined my findings as to ankylostomiasis in Malay States,
stating that I had found there a widespread infection among the coolies on
the rubber estates throughout the Peninsula; that the infection seems to
range from a very light degree in some communities where estate physicians
have been alert in detecting and treating it up to 60% and more on many
groups of estates; that this infection is recognized by the medical profes-
sion and the planters. But that as to what the infection represents as a
menace to health and working efficiency the medical profession is divided
into two opposing camps. One group of doctors maintains that the infection
is a serious handicap; that it lowers the vitality of the coolies and thereby
makes them more susceptible to malaria; that this lowered vitality greatly
increases the death rate attributed to malaria; and that it has a considera-
ble death rate of its own. The other physicians hold that the real scourge
of the country is malaria; that ankylostomiasis as a handicapping disease is
practically negligible; that the anaemia which one sees among the coolies is
due to malaria; that the very high death rate is caused by malaria; that when
the malaria is controlled the death rate falls; and that therefore nothing
more is needed for ankylostomiasis than to treat the cases which come to the
hospitals. After seeing something of conditions from Pinang to Singapore,
and examining clinically about 2,000 coolies on the estates and in the hospi-
tals, I was not prepared to recommend the expenditure of funds either by the
Commission or by the Government in a systematic effort for the relief and
control of the disease on the basis of our present knowledge of the facts.

2. In view of this situation I raised the question as to the
advisability of appointing a commission of experts to settle this question
as to what the ankylostome infection in Malaya represents as a menace to
health and working efficiency. If such commission could determine this ques-
tion for Malaya it could readily do the same thing for any other countries in
the far East where this question has been raised or is likely to come up.
Dr. Heiser advises that just this bit of work needs to be done for the Philip-
pines. He says that he thinks we shall find it necessary to do a similar work
for Cochin China, and probably for Siam. General Gorgas, after hearing the
statement of the case, stated that he saw no grave difficulties in the way of
making a definite determination of the question, and in view of the situation
as outlined, he regarded the appointment of a commission of experts as the
best way to accomplish our purpose.

3. As to the constitution of the commission, he favored the sug-
gestion of having on it one American, one Englishman, and if possible one
local man.

4. I then asked him if in his judgment the prevalence of malaria
in tropical countries offers a fruitful field of service for our Commission.
Malaria, he said, is the scourge of the tropics. It has been demonstrated
that intelligently directed effort for its control gets definite results.
This field, he said, offers the Commission opportunity for large service. But
the work, he reminded me, is expensive and the fight against mosquitoes is a
long one.

I asked him how, in his judgment, the Commission could render most
effective service in this field. He replied, “By making demonstrations in
selected areas.” He said we should select our points with care, get the co-
operation of the communities selected, place at the head of the work a well
trained man, such as La Prince, supply him with a sanitary force, carry the

work as far as possible in the direction of complete control of the disease.
These demonstrations at selected points would teach other communities how to
do the work. The communitirs themselves must in the end assume all the re-
sponsibility for the work.

5. This discussion of malaria suggested the subject of yellow fever.
In this General Gorgas showed the keenest interest. I told him I had found
the people in the far East entertaining considerable anxiety on the subject
of yellow fever as a possibility in those countries as a result of the open-
ing of the Panama Canal. He referred to what Sir Patrick Manson had said
on that subject, and then proceeded to discuss at length the possibility of
eradicating yellow fever from the face of the earth. This, he said, is a
perfectly feasible undertaking; a thing that can be definitely accomplished
within reasonable time and within the limits of a reasonable expenditure.
The Commission, he said, could not undertake a better piece of work than
this. Here is a disease that has commanded an unusual amount of attention,
one in which all tropical and semitropical countries are now keenly interested.
Its eradication would command the attention and the gratitude of the world.
And the thing can be done.

I suggested that we mature a plan for attacking it, he agreed. He
thought it best that we discuss it further before committing any thing to
paper. He left with the understanding that we are to continue our discussion
of this subject with a view to maturing a plan of organization and of work
for the accomplishment of this end.
